caption: Table 1: Results of the synthetic letters experiment for population prediction on seen train populations and unseen test populations. We report the the 1-Wasserstein (W1), 2-Wasserstein (W2), and the maximum-mean-discrepancy (MMD) distributional distances. We consider 4 settings for MFM with varying k.
description: This table presents the results of a synthetic experiment designed to evaluate the performance of different models in predicting letter populations.  The experiment uses four variations of the Meta Flow Matching (MFM) model, each differing in a parameter (k).  The results are reported in terms of three distributional distance metrics: 1-Wasserstein, 2-Wasserstein, and maximum mean discrepancy (MMD), which quantify the difference between the predicted and actual letter distributions.  The results show the performance of the models on both the training (seen) and testing (unseen) populations, which is important for determining the model's ability to generalize.

caption: Table 2: Experimental results on the organoid drug-screen dataset for population prediction of treatment response across replicate populations averaged over co-culture conditions. Results are reported for models trained on data embedded into 10 principle components. We report the the 1-Wasserstein (W1), 2-Wasserstein (W2), and the maximum-mean-discrepancy (MMD) distributional distances. We consider two settings for MFM with varying nearest-neighbours parameter.
description: This table presents the results of the organoid drug-screen dataset experiment.  It shows how well different models predict the treatment response across replicate cell populations, averaging results across multiple cell culture types. The models evaluated are Flow Matching (FM), Input Convex Neural Network (ICNN), Conditional Generative Flow Matching (CGFM), and Meta Flow Matching (MFM) with different hyperparameters (k=0 and k=10). The performance is assessed using three metrics: 1-Wasserstein distance (W1), 2-Wasserstein distance (W2), and Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD). The table compares performance on training and testing datasets to evaluate generalization ability.

caption: Table 2: Experimental results on the organoid drug-screen dataset for population prediction of treatment response across replicate populations averaged over co-culture conditions. Results are reported for models trained on data embedded into 10 principle components. We report the the 1-Wasserstein (W1), 2-Wasserstein (W2), and the maximum-mean-discrepancy (MMD) distributional distances. We consider two settings for MFM with varying nearest-neighbours parameter.
description: This table presents the results of the organoid drug-screen dataset experiment for the population prediction task across replicate populations. The models were trained on data embedded into 10 principal components.  The table reports the 1-Wasserstein (W1), 2-Wasserstein (W2), and maximum-mean discrepancy (MMD) distances for evaluating the performance of Flow Matching (FM), Input Convex Neural Networks (ICNN), Conditional Generation via Flow Matching (CGFM), and Meta Flow Matching (MFM) with k=0 and k=10.  The results are averaged over co-culture conditions.

caption: Table 2: Experimental results on the organoid drug-screen dataset for population prediction of treatment response across replicate populations averaged over co-culture conditions. Results are reported for models trained on data embedded into 10 principle components. We report the the 1-Wasserstein (W1), 2-Wasserstein (W2), and the maximum-mean-discrepancy (MMD) distributional distances. We consider two settings for MFM with varying nearest-neighbours parameter.
description: This table presents the results of experiments using the organoid drug-screen dataset to predict treatment response across different replicates (control and treatment population pairs).  The models were trained using data embedded into 10 principle components.  The performance is evaluated using three distributional distance metrics: 1-Wasserstein (W1), 2-Wasserstein (W2), and Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD). The table compares the performance of different models (FM, ICNN, CGFM, and MFM with different k values) on both training and testing datasets.  Note that Meta Flow Matching (MFM) is tested with two different values of k (nearest neighbors), allowing for a comparison of model performance with different embedding strategies.

caption: Table 2: Experimental results on the organoid drug-screen dataset for population prediction of treatment response across replicate populations averaged over co-culture conditions. Results are reported for models trained on data embedded into 10 principle components. We report the the 1-Wasserstein (W1), 2-Wasserstein (W2), and the maximum-mean-discrepancy (MMD) distributional distances. We consider two settings for MFM with varying nearest-neighbours parameter.
description: This table presents the results of the organoid drug-screen experiment for predicting treatment responses across replicate populations.  The results are averaged across different co-culture conditions and use data embedded into 10 principle components.  Three different distance metrics (1-Wasserstein, 2-Wasserstein, and Maximum Mean Discrepancy) are reported for four models: FM, ICNN, CGFM, and MFM (with two different k values). The table shows performance on both training and test sets, enabling comparison of model generalization.
